title: Childhood vaccines: 'huge benefits, minimal risk' - VaccinesToday
author: Editorial Team
description: Are vaccines safe and effective for children?
cleaned_text: This is the most fundamental and reasonable question every parents asks before following the recommended immunisation schedule. The answer, according to study after the study, is an emphatic yes. The latest scientific paper to explore the question of vaccine safety is [a review published in Pediatrics](http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/134/2/325), a leading journal. Researchers looked at dozens of quality research papers on the [safety of the vaccines](http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/134/2/325) recommended for children in the US (most of which are similar to those [recommenced for children in Europe](http://vaccine-schedule.ecdc.europa.eu/Pages/Scheduler.aspx)). It found that serious problems following vaccination were 'extremely rare' and usually resolved quickly, adding that this very small risk is heavily outweighed by the 'protective benefits that vaccines provide'. In an [accompanying commentary](http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/134/2/377) by Dr Carrie Byington, a leading US paediatrician, it is argued that being more open about rare adverse events could be reassuring - at least for doctors who can then offer confident reassurance to their patients.
